resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
ilya-biryukov opened a new pull request #9662:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9662


   `PrimitiveBuilder<u8>` was performing a lot of unnecessary bit operations.
   One operation for each byte of each string one appends.
   
   Delaying the creation of null bitmap builder for `PrimitiveBuilder`
   significantly improves performance of `StringBuilder`. The optimization is
   also generally useful as the null bitmap is not stored if resulting
   arrays do not contain nulls.
   
   Results from the added benchmark on my machine are:
   
   ```
   bench_primitive/bench_string
                           time:   [6.8971 ms 6.9123 ms 6.9335 ms]
                           thrpt:  [937.48 MiB/s 940.35 MiB/s 942.43 MiB/s]
                    change:
                           time:   [-49.585% -49.395% -49.204%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                           thrpt:  [+96.867% +97.610% +98.355%]
                           Performance has improved.
   ```


----------------------------------------------------------------

Dandandan commented on pull request #9662:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9662#issuecomment-794138752


   Thanks a lot @ilya-biryukov the builders are not so efficient at the moment indeed.
   
   I think the future directlion of creating data seems to go more in the direction of using iterators / collect() for creating arrow arrays.
   
   Alternatively I think we could have non-null builders which would not create a bitmap and miss the append_null method.

   Thanks a lot @ilya-biryukov the builders are not so efficient at the moment indeed.
   
   I think the future directlion of creating data seems to go more in the direction of using iterators / collect() for creating arrow arrays.
   
   Alternatively I think we could have non-null builders which would not create a bitmap and leave the append_null method in that case.

ilya-biryukov commented on pull request #9662:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9662#issuecomment-796645420


   @Dandandan if the input data is generated from existing Rust datastructures/code, using iterators and collect actually does make a lot of sense. 
   
   I believe our use-case will still be centered around the builders. We're looking at speeding up some `datafusion` operations and an extra round-trip through Rust representation would slow things down. Building with iterators looks hard at times, e.g. efficiently constructing an array of strings is actually much simpler with `StringBuilder` than directly in Rust, as `String` allocates on the heap and this can add up when the Strings are many.
   
   > Alternatively I think we could have non-null builders which would not create a bitmap and leave the append_null method in that case.
   Actually I would argue that the current approach makes a lot of sense. Nulls don't add that much runtime overhead and adding new buidlers will probably add up to the complexity. Applying the trick from this commit for builders would bring performance really close to optimal, up to a point that this should almost never become a problem in practice.
   Note that `PrimitiveBuilder<u8>` is a somewhat pathological case when used inside `StringBuilder`. Paying for bit-set operation on each byte inside the every added string is just too expensive. 


----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

Dandandan commented on pull request #9662:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9662#issuecomment-796686685


   @ilya-biryukov 
   Thanks for updating it with a benchmark. I think this PR is good to go for me as it seems a net win based on the benchmark results. Can you solve the clippy lint?
   
   I am not sure I follow you 100% on using the iterator to build an arrow string array. They are implemented for `&str` as well, so they don't copy the data and should instead translate into a more simple loop. Additionaly, they can pre-allocate the indices array if using an iterator with known size, so they are/should be more efficient than the string builder.
   I think we should have a look at the cases where DataFusion is currently using the builder and if possible translate it to use the iterator API.


----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

ilya-biryukov commented on pull request #9662:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9662#issuecomment-796776561


   @Dandandan 
   
   > @ilya-biryukov
   > Thanks for updating it with a benchmark. I think this PR is good to go for me as it seems a net win based on the benchmark results. Can you solve the clippy lint?
   
   Done.
   
   > I am not sure I follow you 100% on using the iterator to build an arrow string array. They are implemented for `&str` as well, so they don't copy the data and should instead translate into a more simple loop.
   
   The use-case I tried to describe involves [building arrays of unknown length](https://github.com/cube-js/arrow/blob/40e2f0e7e596c71ec9016fef9842e2fbff1ff125/rust/datafusion/src/physical_plan/sorted_aggregate.rs#L23) from multiple inputs that get [sent in batches](https://github.com/cube-js/arrow/blob/40e2f0e7e596c71ec9016fef9842e2fbff1ff125/rust/datafusion/src/physical_plan/sorted_aggregate.rs#L69).
   
   
   I can hardly see anything more convenient than builders here. But this is definitely not the typical use-case, iterator-based APIs are more convenient in most cases.
   
   > Additionaly, they can pre-allocate the indices array if using an iterator with known size, so they are/should be more efficient than the string builder.
   > I think we should have a look at the cases where DataFusion is currently using the builder and if possible translate it to use the iterator API.
   
   Note that the code I linked is **not** upstream  DataFusion, it's from our fork. I should have mentioned that explicitly when mentioning DataFusion in the first place to avoid potential confusion.

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
The corresponding GitHub PR produces a good performance improvement when building string arrays (especially if the total length of the strings is large).

See the PR for details.
